poem:
### The Unmasking

In the child's bright eye,  
truths flicker like candle flames.  
December's mystery,  
unraveled in sneaker soles,  
uncle's laughter veiled,  
beneath borrowed myth.  
We seek the adult's world,  
but find only echoes  
in a jingled temple,  
where gifts spark briefly  
before fading into  
the long, quiet winter night.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Christmas that went wrong: Why on earth was Santa wearing my uncle’s sneakers? As a child, I was an amateur detective; a master of argument and the suspicious side-eye. The adult world seemed to be defined by determined, capable people making important decisions and I was desperate to be one of them. In short, I was precocious. And I’m sorry to everybody I came up against. Especially my uncle Dan. Christmas 1989 was exciting for four-year-old". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
